results.title: The Long Tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Les Humanoïdes Associés and Dan O'Bannon
results.brief_description:
Colour printed copy of comic book ‘Moebius - The long tomorrow’, by Les Humanoides Associes; hard cover edition. 56 pages, 21.2 x 29 cm , colour edition
ISBN 9782731673845
results.description: The Long Tomorrow is the title of a science fiction comics short story serialised in two segments in the French magazine Metal Hurlant in 1976. It was written by Dan O’Bannon, and illustrated by Moebius. It is noted for its influential visual design, which inspired the designs of feature films including Tron, Alien, and The Abyss.
description_for_label:
Colour printed copy of comic book ‘Moebius - The long tomorrow’, by Les Humanoides Associes; hard cover edition. 56 pages, 21.2 x 29 cm , colour edition
ISBN 9782731673845

results.title: Phenakistiscope disc (Politeness)
results.brief_description: The phenakistoscope is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc is fitted to the device and when seen through the slots, comes to life.
results.description:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistoscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.
description_for_label:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistoscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.

results.title: Magic lantern set effects slide (Les jouers de cartes - the card players)
results.brief_description: Hand painted magic lantern set effects slipping slide in wooden frame [Les Jouers de Cartes - the Card Players]. By sliding the effects slide, two card players’ heads turn in to a chicken (left) and a dog (right).
